content.body: proposes something which would end up making alt="" required for every image
i'll be interested to see whether the alt-must-be-required-whether-useful-or-not camp like this proposal or not
Sounds kind of similar to the 'noalt' thing that people have suggested
except with more graceful degradation in UAs that do ugly things with without alt
and sometimes slightly more informative to users than always announcing the image as "Image"

I suppose the problem is that people will just never bother adding 'importantimage', because it achieves no visible effect (including in validators) - UAs don't know that images without importantimage are unimportant, so they'll still have to let their users interact with alt-less images in case they're important, so there would be no difference

Hixie: Hmm. Seems to me that if the use-case includes bulk-upload photo tools, then those tools can't make the statement that the image "cannot be considered equivalent to any text". What they can do is say the alt is not in any sense a full equivalent to the image.
that would be useful information to tools like Lynx
They could say how confident they are in the quality of the alt text, like
I'm not sure that would add much to current use scenarios over just saying it's not a full equivalent.
Indeed, it seems a hard enough job just to get people to use a boolean value correctly
if you've got some hypothetical future gizmo for recognizing images, you're likely to just run it over anything that isn't q=1
You should run it on anything that is q=1 too, because people will use q=1 when they've got rubbish alt text
Philip`: If you've got another hypothetical future gizmo that tells you whether you're new equivalent is better than the original alt, maybe.
*your new

webben_: I've got a concrete present-day human who can decide whether the original alt text is giving them the information they're expecting or hoping for, and if not then they can use the gizmo and decide whether that's any better
um, yes, although the information they're expecting or hoping for might be rather different to that actually intended to be provided.
but quering an analysis tool is different to running it automatically
(or at least to presenting the results automatically)

I'm thinking of e.g. looking at a Flickr page and finding a thing called "Photo" or "IMG_05863.JPG" and then (regardless of how reliable the page says that alt text is) choosing to analyse it in more detail
yep, that would work.

I'm not sure how it'd be possible to do the analysis automatically, since you'd want an extremely concise output (like one or two words) in most cases, else it'll significantly disrupt the flow of the page
depends how clever the gizmo is, it's all a bit speculative at this point
At least it could ignore transparent spacer GIFs
yes. We really ought to be able to improve at to ignore space GIFs now.
*improve AT

Aside: Maybe HTML5 should support <spacer>, since that's a better solution than spacer GIFs because it's easier for UAs to ignore it, but currently it's unfashionable because it makes validators complain
and Lynx for that matter.
webben_: Do most ATs download images?
I've never run across an instance of a developer needing a spacer GIF, so I know no reason to support either except to deal with existing content.
(I assume they would if they're just stuck on top of IE or Firefox or whatever)
It'd be kind of a pain to make Lynx download every linked image file solely to decide whether it looks like a spacer or not
Philip`: Most AT isn't a browser, but acting with a browser. People using AT don't necessarily turn off image downloading, though some do.
Philip`: css is a better solution
Hixie: Oh, good point
Philip`: Depends how annoying seeing "SPACER GIF" splattered across the page is to lynx users, I guess
or IMAGE when it's not one.
You're probably right that text browsers' commitment to speed is going to make them even less capable than typical AT.

wonders if someone like Google could download and analyse every image on the internet, then construct something like a Bloom filter so UAs can quickly check whether a given URI is in the pre-computed set of spacer images, and how large the filter data file would be
tricky, given images are obtained via URIs, and URIs can return things that vary by who requests them (as well as time)
you could md5 the downloaded image and use that for the query to a webservice, but that would still require Lynx to download the image
Static content like images are more commonly at a single static URI, so it might not be too awful
Oh yes, it would work for common cases.
having to make a request to a webservice for each image might be almost as bad for performance as downloading the images in the first place
Hmm, Google says there's about 10^9 images, and if I wildly guess there's 10^6 spacer images, and an acceptable false positive rate is 1/1000, then it'd only need 14MB of filter data
webben_: The idea is that you just download the global data once, and do local queries on that, like how Firefox's phishing filter works by default
oh I see.
Anyway, this a stupid idea so I'll drop it :-p
Oops, that's 14Mbits, so it's not even 2MB
